newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: SFE wheat futures fall on Chicago slide.
newsitem.headline: SFE wheat futures fall on Chicago slide.

text.p: Australian wheat futures fell on Friday in line with Chicago's overnight decline.

January 1998 fell by A$4.50 a tonne to A$172.00 on 18 lots while nearby July traded down by A$1.50 to A$199.00 on 10 lots. Settlement prices showed support in the near-term months where physical supply is tight, but fell by about A$3.00 a tonne in more distant contracts. Gary Booth of Ord Minnett Jardine Fleming Futures said the Australian market followed the U.S. market's downward break through key support levels.
But grains markets remained very tight, he said.

Rain in northern New South Wales had improved initial crop prospects but good follow-0n rain was still needed in Australia's southeast. The continued presence of the El Nino weather pattern made the prospect of good follow-on rain less likely than the prospect of it occurring, Booth said.
Australian wheat futures prices in relation to U.S. prices were about A$20.00 a tonne higher than last year, he said.
This reflected continued drought feeding, the need for more rain in southern areas, concern about the quality of the crop and Australia's low carryover of wheat, he said.
